# Draft:Jeremy King (restaurateur)

----
----
Jeremy King OBE (born 21 June 1954) is a British restaurateur and author. He is best known for co-founding Corbin & King, the restaurant group behind The Wolseley, The Delaunay and Brasserie Zédel, and has been described by The Financial Times as “one of London’s most influential restaurateurs.”. In 2014 he was appointed Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) for services to the hospitality industry and the arts. In 2022 he launched Jeremy King Restaurants, which operates Arlington (formerly Le Caprice) and [https://www.theparkrestaurant.com The Park], with a relaunch of Simpson’s in the Strand planned for 2026.
Career
In 1973, King worked as a part-time barman at Charco’s, a wine bar in Chelsea, and was later promoted to assistant general manager while awaiting entry to the University of Cambridge. At the age of 21, influenced by Luke Rhinehart’s novel The Dice Man, King decided to pursue a career in hospitality if he secured a managerial role within a month. He was soon promoted to manager at Charco’s.
In 1979, he became Maître d’hôtel at Joe Allen in Covent Garden, London, during which he met his future business partner Chris Corbin. In September 1981, the pair, together with retailer Joseph Ettedgui, opened Le Caprice on Arlington Street, St James’s. Under Caprice Holdings, King and Corbin relaunched The Ivy and J. Sheekey before selling majority control to former restaurant operator Belgo Group Plc and leaving the company in 2000.
In 2003, King and Corbin opened The Wolseley on Piccadilly followed by St Alban in 2006. They later launched The Delaunay (2011), Brasserie Zédel (2012), Colbert (2012), Fischer’s (2014), The Beaumont Hotel (2014), Bellanger (2015), and Soutine (2019). They were also briefly involved with the Monkey Bar in New York between 2009 and 2011. St Alban was sold in 2009, and in 2018 Grosvenor sold the long leasehold of The Beaumont.
In 2017, Minor International acquired a majority shareholding in Corbin & King, and in April 2022 gained full control of the company following an administration process and auction. The reported purchase price was over £60 million
In 2022, King founded Jeremy King Restaurants, which has since opened Arlington (formerly Le Caprice), The Park on Queensway. A third restaurant, Simpson’s in the Strand, is scheduled to open in 2026.
Affiliations
King has held board and trustee positions with Tate, Soho Theatre, and the Chelsea Arts Club. He has been depicted in works by Tom Phillips and Lucian Freud, who produced both a painted portrait and an etching.
Publications
King collaborated with British writer and critic A. A. Gill on several books related to his restaurants. These include: The Ivy: The Restaurant and its Recipes (April 1999), Le Caprice (November 1999), Breakfast at The Wolseley (May 2008) and Brasserie Zédel: Traditions and Recipes from a Grand Brasserie (July 2016). His autobiography, [https://www.amazon.com/Without-Reservation-Lessons-Life-Restaurants/dp/0008599025?ref_=ast_author_mpb&author-follow=B0FTZGV7LK Without Reservation: Lessons from a Life in Restaurants] was published on 09 Oct 2025 by HarperCollins under the imprint Fourth Estate.
Awards and honours
He was named Restaurateur of the Year by Caterer & Hotelkeeper in 1993, Entrepreneur of the Year by GQ in 2012, and received Lifetime Achievement Awards from GQ (2015), Harden’s (2017), and The Cateys (2022). In 2014, he was awarded an Honorary Master of Science (Hon MSc) by the University of West London, and was appointed Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) in the New Year Honours for services to hospitality and voluntary service to the arts.
Personal life
King is married to Lauren Gurvich-King, a real estate developer and content producer. His first marriage was to Debra Hauer, an American psychotherapist and former theatre producer from Walnut Creek, California. He has three children, including Jonah Hauer-King.
